title: Estimated Average Glucose (eAG) From HbA1C
description: Estimates average glucose level from Hemoglobin A1C value using the linear relationship established by the A1c-Derived Average Glucose (ADAG) Study Group.

parameters.name: hba1c_percent
parameters.description: Hemoglobin A1C value as a percentage

result.name: estimated_average_glucose
result.description: Estimated average glucose level in mg/dL

ranges.interpretation: Estimated average glucose is within normal range. HbA1c <5.7% indicates normal glucose metabolism. Continue healthy lifestyle habits including regular physical activity, balanced diet, and weight management. Regular monitoring may be appropriate based on individual risk factors.

Estimated average glucose suggests prediabetes (HbA1c 5.7-6.4%). This indicates increased risk of developing type 2 diabetes. Lifestyle interventions including weight loss, increased physical activity, and dietary modifications are recommended. Regular monitoring and diabetes prevention programs may be beneficial.

Estimated average glucose indicates diabetes (HbA1c ≥6.5%) with relatively good glycemic control. The American Diabetes Association suggests target HbA1c <7% (eAG <154 mg/dL) for most nonpregnant adults with diabetes. Continue current diabetes management plan with regular monitoring and healthcare provider follow-up.

Estimated average glucose indicates diabetes with moderate glycemic control (HbA1c 7.5-9.0%). Consider intensification of diabetes management including medication adjustment, lifestyle modification, diabetes education, and more frequent monitoring. Work with healthcare provider to optimize treatment plan.

Estimated average glucose indicates diabetes with poor glycemic control (HbA1c >9.0%). Immediate intensification of diabetes management is recommended. This may include insulin therapy, comprehensive medication review, diabetes education, and frequent monitoring. Risk of diabetic complications is significantly increased. Urgent consultation with endocrinologist or diabetes specialist may be appropriate.

references: Nathan DM, Kuenen J, Borg R, Zheng H, Schoenfeld D, Heine RJ. Translating the A1C assay into estimated average glucose values. Diabetes Care. 2008;31(8):1473-8. doi: 10.2337/dc08-0545.
American Diabetes Association. 6. Glycemic Targets: Standards of Medical Care in Diabetes-2021. Diabetes Care. 2021;44(Suppl 1):S73-S84. doi: 10.2337/dc21-S006.
International Expert Committee. International Expert Committee report on the role of the A1C assay in the diagnosis of diabetes. Diabetes Care. 2009;32(7):1327-34. doi: 10.2337/dc09-9033.

Rohlfing CL, Wiedmeyer HM, Little RR, England JD, Tennill A, Goldstein DE. Defining the relationship between plasma glucose and HbA(1c): analysis of glucose profiles and HbA(1c) in the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial. Diabetes Care. 2002;25(2):275-8. doi: 10.2337/diacare.25.2.275.
formula: eAG (mg/dL) = (28.7 × HbA1c %) - 46.7. This linear relationship was established by the A1c-Derived Average Glucose (ADAG) Study Group with r²=0.84.
notes: The eAG/A1C represents an average of glucose levels 24 hours a day over 2-3 months, reflecting the average lifespan of red blood cells.
eAG is not the same as the average of readings on a glucose meter, as it includes periods when glucose is typically not measured (e.g., post-meal periods).
The formula was derived from the A1c-Derived Average Glucose (ADAG) Study Group and has a correlation coefficient (r²) of 0.84.
HbA1c reflects average glucose levels over approximately 2-3 months, with more recent glucose levels having greater influence.
Normal HbA1c is <5.7%, prediabetes is 5.7-6.4%, and diabetes is ≥6.5% according to American Diabetes Association criteria.
The eAG provides a way to relate HbA1c values to everyday glucose monitoring values that patients see on their meters.
Individual variation exists, and some patients may have higher or lower average glucose levels than predicted by their HbA1c.
The relationship may be affected by conditions that alter red blood cell lifespan, hemoglobin variants, or other factors.
eAG values are expressed in mg/dL (US units). To convert to mmol/L (international units), divide by 18.0.
This tool complements, but does not replace, regular glucose monitoring and clinical assessment.
The American Diabetes Association target for most nonpregnant adults with diabetes is HbA1c <7% (eAG <154 mg/dL).
More stringent targets (HbA1c <6.5%) may be appropriate for some patients if achievable without significant hypoglycemia.
Less stringent targets (HbA1c <8%) may be appropriate for patients with limited life expectancy or significant comorbidities.
eAG should be interpreted in the context of the patient's overall clinical picture and diabetes management plan.
